Award.AwardTitle: K-theory of Operator Algebras and Its Applications to Geometry and Topology
Award.AbstractNarration:
In classical geometry, one studies geometric objects whose coordinates commute. Noncommutative geometry is a mathematical theory specifically designed to handle "geometric objects" whose coordinates do not commute but which do occur naturally in mathematics and physics. In the last decade or so, with the help of new ideas from noncommutative geometry, there have been a series of advances towards the solutions of long-standing problems in classical geometry and topology. Higher index theory serves as a bridge between noncommutative geometry and classical geometry and topology. The principal investigator and his students plan to apply noncommutative geometry methods to study problems in differential geometry and topology.

The K-groups of certain operator algebras are receptacles of higher indices of elliptic differential operators and have important applications to problems in differential geometry and in the topology of manifolds. Examples of such applications include estimation of the size of the moduli space of all Riemannian metrics with positive scalar curvature and questions concerning the rigidity or nonrigidity of a manifold. The principal investigator intends to apply the techniques of controlled operator K-theory, dynamic complexity, and finite embeddability into Banach spaces to study K-theory of operator algebras and higher index theory. He also intends to apply noncommutative geometry methods to study analysis on infinite-dimensional spaces (e.g., loop spaces of manifolds).

Project Outcomes Report:

Introduction: In classical geometry, one studies geometric objects whose coordinates commute. Noncommutative geometry is a mathematical theory specifically designed to handle "geometric objects" whose coordinates do not commute but which do occur naturally in mathematics and physics. In the last decade or so, with the help of new ideas from noncommutative geometry, there have been a series of advances towards the solutions of long-standing problems in classical geometry and topology. Higher invariants of differential operators serves as a bridge between noncommutative geometry and classical geometry and topology. The principal investigator and his collaborators applies noncommutative geometry methods to study problems in differential geometry and topology.

Intellectual Merit: Working with his collaborators, PI has solved several long standing open problems such as the additivity of certain higher invariants of differential operators, computation of K-theory, and algebraic K-theory Novikov conjecture with certain coefficients. These results have important applications to geometry and topology of manifolds.

Broad Impact: The PI is actively involved in the training the next generation of young mathematicians in noncommutative geometry and operator algebras. Currently the PI is  supervising five PhD students and two postdocs at Texas A&M University. During the period of this grant, three of the PI's PhD students finished their thesis and found postdoc positions at research universities and two of postdocs found tenure track positions in research departments. The PI is co-organizing the Noncommutative Geometry Seminar and the Math Circle at Texas A&M. The PI co-organized a dozen of conferences including the Oberwolfach workshop on Noncommutative Geometry and IWOTA in 2018. The PI gave several mini courses at conferences.
